title: Friday, 30th August 2019
bodyHTML:
marktime dobryj den
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Morning.

marktime Ferrexpo MAY have a confession ... that is like a soft signal for OUT?

I think my favourite email this morning was this one:

Dr B Morning BE
2s10s Howdy
BE11:15am

Markkus morning

Yep. That's market reporting in a nutshell.

Of course, we can automate it now.

https://talktotransformer.com/

Burt morning...any idea why inmarsat seems to be trading a few % above its agreed takeover price today? thanks

BE11:17am

BE11:18am

(@2s10s: we've been running liveblogs on these pixels for quite a while ...)

BE11:18am

But anyway, let's get on with Friday.

11:18 am
undefined
sprout @2s10s - the FT's weekly politics podcast is the best one out there, IMO.
BE11:19am

Ferrexpo, Intu, Berlin landlords, maybe some autos, Grafton to come.

marktime If we are moving to a four day week ...
BE11:20am

As well as Petrofac, which has had a bit of a spike on very very strong volume.

11:20 am
Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 421.30, up 19.5 (+4.85%), High: 424.00, Low: 390.90, Volume: 969.31k
Shinshin @marktime Finally a Corbyn policy everyone can get behind
BE11:21am

There is not, as far as I know, anything out of the SFO

Shrink Afternoon everyone
Blank canvas good morning. Is it 3 September already?
BE11:23am

But ... anyway, we'll head into grift later. Too dangerous to put untested gossip this far up the transcript ....

marktime Has there been a sector upgrade Wood Group also strong
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Instead, we can kick off with Ferrexpo, which has delivered a kind of off-whitewash.

Ferrexpo PLC (FXPO:LSE): Last: 202.60, up 3.65 (+1.83%), High: 206.80, Low: 186.00, Volume: 1.02m
BE11:25am

The Farrow & Ball of Independent reviews. Yes, some money to the charity might've gone elsewhere .....

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Independent committee says it cannot explain a number of discrepancies in the 2018 Annual Report relating to the use of funds and indications remain that some funds might have been misappropriated.

BE11:27am

But none of Ferrexpo's directors, management, or employees had any involvement in any possible misappropriation

marktime Who audited Ferrexpo then?
BE11:28am

Which of course leaves an obvious category of person for the possible misappropriation. Here's Caz:

11:28 am
BE11:29am

The release also states that FXPO’s board will now consider further steps regarding the potential misappropriation of funds from the Charity. We expect this could include possible legal action to recover the funds in question, but we do not ascribe any value upside potential from this given the considerable uncertainty. FXPO previously guided that it believed the impact of the irregularities to be only ~$9.5m. Additionally, Bloomberg recently reported that the Blooming Lands Charity’s Kiev office was searched by tax investigators. However, little information has so far come out of this so it is not possible to deduce anything regarding this recent search about the Ferrexpo investigations.

BE11:29am

FXPO’s valuation remains extremely cheap vs our EMEA Mining &
Steel coverage, on 2.5x/2.4x spot 2019E/20E EV/EBITDA and 21%/25% FCF yields. This offers FXPO significant cash returns potential in 2019, but we do not expect any re-rating while the various investigations weigh on investor sentiment.

BornCynic Morning BE - did you enjoy the holiday?
marktime Was Deloitte and Touche, incoming a franchise of Baker Tilly sounds like a knitwear supplier replacing some nits
undefined
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Sorry, brief pause, conversations happening offscreen.

BE11:33am

So .......... Intu.

Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 41.62, up 3.84 (+10.16%), High: 42.59, Low: 38.49, Volume: 2.31m
11:34 am
BE11:34am

An extremely strong bounce on no news whatsoever, either current or expected.

BE11:35am

Now, the risk case for Intu's many shorters has always been a take private.

A. M. (morning all)
BE11:36am

John Whitakker has 29 per cent of the shares and had put together an offer only a year ago at .......... 210p wasn't it? ....

11:37 am
BE11:38am

That's the kind of speculation that seems to be interesting the punters this morning. And a 10% share price move suggests that, if anything needs to be said, Intu will need to say it.

BE11:38am

However, remember also that very large short to get squeezed on any kind of rumour.

Viking1 Meanwhile RTN figures on Tuesday, any preview note out. Stock making new 2019 highs
BE11:40am

A reminder also that the equity's only worth slightly north of £500m now

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:40am

Speaking of real estate, Berlin .....

BE11:41am

And the rent freeze that turns out not to be a rent freeze

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Local reports suggesting inflation linking and applying the cap only for low-income households, which it defines as 30% of income on rent.

BE11:42am

[Cue the hollow laugh from Londoners]

BE11:42am

Oh, and implementation seems to be a while off as well.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Deutsche Wohnen and the other one, Vonthingy, sharply higher in reaction. Here's Caz again.

BE11:43am

Up until this morning, we think expectations in the market went potentially as far as: A five year rent
freeze coming into force in January 2020 (effective Jun-19) which could take up to 5 years to be potentially
deemed unconstitutional by the Federal Constitutional Court with further risk of rent ceilings based on
construction year (click here). Today, it appears moderate rent increases may be possible, while the law is not
expected to come into force in 2020 and rent ceilings may only apply to apartments where 30% of household
income is spent on rent.
 Our Deutsche Wohnen base case with a PT of €38 assumes no residential rental growth - which given
this morning’s news could be too conservative - and 1.3% p.a. capital growth. We would flag that on DW’s
1H19 Conf Call, management noted that based on average income in Berlin, the total rental burden for tenants
in their portfolio was c.18% or c. 25% at market levels. The 30% of net household income limit mentioned
today in the press is what Deutsche Wohnen proposed in its voluntary social rental policy earlier this year,
suggesting there is likely to still be upside from the current level in their portfolio.

BE11:44am

And Morgan Stanley.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Reports are unconfirmed, but if true, this would provide material relief for the shares. What's new? As part of the Berlin Senate's procedure to introduce its proposed Mietendeckel (rent freeze) regulation, the consultation procedures have resulted in a likely dilution of the proposed measures, press articles (eg berlin-bz.de, Tagesspiegel) suggest. We make three observations:1. Positive: No more rent freeze, inflation linking instead. According to the articles, rather than an absolute rent freeze for 5 years, the Berlin Senate could instead favour moderate rental increases capped by the annual rate of inflation. This would be a material positive.2. Uncertain: No clarity on modernisation. The draft Mietendeckel proposal also intends to reduce modernisation capex profitability in a significant way. Modernisation has been a material driver for rents for the listed landlords. Today's press articles do not make comments on this. 3. Positive: Proposed rent cap changed and potentially delayed, even likely still to be introduced for some tenants. The article also suggests that a rent cap (with a potential rent reduction) would only be applicable to tenants paying more than 30% of income, and that the measure for the maximum rent would be set at the 2013 Mietspiegel level rather than the 2011 level, with building age still an important factor. The article also said that the rent cap law will not be completed as planned in January. Our views. If what is suggested by these article were to materialise, the outcome for Deutsche Wohnen, and any peers with Berlin exposure, is materially less bad than feared. Deutsche Wohnen's ability to drive rents would likely be reduced, and its like for like rental growth would fall from around 3% currently but only modestly so (2018 inflation was 2%), we estimate. Note that the group already self-imposes several of the measures that are proposed such as the rent cap for tenants with stretched affordability (see Deutsche Wohnen: Alternative proposals to rent freeze, dated 24 June).Background. The Berlin Senate has approved the Berlin SPD's proposal to start the legislative procedure to introduce a 5 year residential rent freeze (a.k.a. Mietendeckel). Based on the current timetable such a rent freeze could be implemented by January 2020. We are on the sidelines and rate Deutsche Wohnen Equal-weight. If rents are frozen for a period of 5 years, Deutsche Wohnen's return profile looks very different.

andyalan10 5 minutes without a comment, help Bryce out. Any grey on Microfocus please?
Shinshin Ah, rent caps. Policy failure in two words. "Hey, our economic policies are encouraging more people to move here" "Great!" "But that means we run out of houses so we'll need to build more" "Oh no that would be terrible let's just cap rents instead, because that will encourage more people to move here"
undefined
2s10s rent caps are good.
A. M. Perhaps the cap ought to be on the rent increase, rather than the amount itself.
BE11:47am

(@andyalan10: it's cool, we're still in the summer shutdown. These sessions always exist in a quiet hinterland of comments in the mid double figures.)

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Micro Focus? Righty ho.

Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 1,122, up 70.4 (+6.70%), High: 1,126, Low: 1,051, Volume: 891.33k
chopper bear any grey on HZM by any chance - I know its a small cap - but its pretty interesting as glencore are watching carefully
BE11:49am

It's a deat cat, to state the obvious.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Morning press coverage seems more focused on the strategic plan than the sales warning. Mentions of it potentially selling Autonomy and that kind of thing.

BE11:51am

(And good luck getting a decent price there!)

A. M. (could it be that the push towards SaaS is the real killer of MF's business model?)
BE11:53am

Let me see if there's anything worth adding to yesterday's stuff.

2s10s @A.M. , et al: what stocks are a good SaaS play please?
Shinshin @BE Time for an early lunch in the last of the sunshine ?
11:55 am
BE11:55am

............ um, no. Not a single buyer in my email. Sorry. That was a bit of a cul-de-sac.

undefined
chopper bear petrofac?
A. M. @2s10: no idea.. what I meant was, roughly, this -- MF is where enterprise software goes to spend its twilight years. However, if everything is located in the vendors' respective clouds, how would such a handover work?
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR - enjoy the weekend.
2s10s @A.M. sure, I agree. I was just wondering on a SWOT analysis.
A. M. @2s10: that would require more inputs than the cup of coffee I've just had, I'm afraid.
BE11:57am

Sorry for slowness. Other things going on and doing ML's currently third priority ..........

11:57 am
BE11:57am

For that reason we'll wind up a tad early.

BE11:58am

Head over here to read things about stuff: https://www.ft.com...-af46-b09e8bfe60c0

Blank canvas thanks BE - good to have you back this week
BE11:58am

And we'll try harder next week.

2s10s cheers bye
A. M. @BE: thanks, have a pleasant weekend.
Irish HF guy @s2a10, you need decide the sector of SaaS and then which companies in that sector. In my experience the expensive stock in the sector is for a reason and tends to outperform the sector. For example when IBM bought Red Hat I looked at Mongo DB, (share price has doubled since) same as CSaaS Twilio, Vonage 8x8 etc, I could go on but not enough time
Irish HF guy thanks BE, have a great weekend
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Thanks, and afternoon all.

2s10s @Irish HF: thanks.
